entries.content: Perfection is a myth. Focus on production and volume, not getting stuck trying to be perfect. Continuous improvement matters more.
Don't let perfect be the enemy of the good. Stay in the fight and keep getting better.
Cultivate genuine curiosity about the other person, their business, problems, and goals. People feel your authenticity.
Genuine curiosity allows you to ask deeper, more insightful questions and listen more effectively.
Use the 'unqualified yes' technique to get micro agreements throughout the conversation. These don't mean they will buy.
Unqualified yeses build momentum, rapport, and make it easier for the prospect to continue saying yes, paving the way for the final yes.
Prospect saying 'Yeah, that's exactly what we're dealing with' is an example of an unqualified yes.
Asking 'Would you agree that X is important?' and the prospect saying 'Yes' is getting an unqualified yes.
Use phrases like 'So, if I understand correctly, you're saying that...' to confirm and get an unqualified yes ('Yes, that's right').
Use 'mirroring' to subtly match the prospect's tone, pace, and language. This builds rapport and trust.
Anchor expectations upfront before a demo or proposal. This reduces pressure and builds trust.
Anchor meetings with 'If by the end of this, you don't feel comfortable, that's perfectly okay. There's no pressure at all.'
entries.notes: Use before deep engagement like a demo

entries.content: Anchor meetings with 'We'll spend about 20 minutes exploring needs, and then if it makes sense, talk next steps. If it doesn't, no worries.'

entries.content: Always be qualifying. Continuously assess if the prospect is a good fit (decision-maker, budget, problem, readiness).
Qualifying should happen throughout the entire interaction, not just at the beginning. This saves time.
Use questions to guide the conversation instead of making statements. Questions reveal needs and help prospects feel heard.
Good questions guide the prospect toward understanding how your solution can help them.
Use discovery questions like 'What are your biggest challenges with X?'
Use impact questions like 'How is that impacting your business?'
Use questions about past efforts like 'What have you tried to solve this?'
Use questions about desired outcomes like 'What would success look like?'
Use questions about ideal state like 'If you could wave a magic wand, what would change?'
Understand the importance of your tone of voice. It conveys confidence, sincerity, and authority.
Practice varying your tone: enthusiastic for solutions, empathetic for problems, calm and confident overall.
A confident, genuine tone builds trust and makes your message more persuasive. Avoid robotic or pushy tones.
Your tone is a crucial part of your personal brand in sales.
